articles.headline: The ‘Man Show’ Diaspora
articles.snippet: The Comedy Central raunch-fest didn’t seem like it would be politically relevant two decades later. But that was long before Joe Rogan interviewed presidential candidates and Pete Buttigieg filled in for Jimmy Kimmel.
articles.abstract: The Comedy Central raunch-fest didn’t seem like it would be politically relevant two decades later. But that was long before Joe Rogan interviewed presidential candidates and Pete Buttigieg filled in for Jimmy Kimmel.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s possible you do not remember “The Man Show.” Or perhaps you don’t want to.
articles.byline: By Jessica Bennett

articles.headline: House Passes Coronavirus Relief After Democrats Strike Deal With White House
articles.snippet: Democrats dropped a proposal to establish a new paid sick leave entitlement for public health emergencies and added tax credits for small- and medium-size businesses requested by Republicans.
articles.abstract: Democrats dropped a proposal to establish a new paid sick leave entitlement for public health emergencies and added tax credits for small- and medium-size businesses requested by Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump declared a national emergency on Friday over the coronavirus pandemic and announced steps he said would speed the availability of testing, and early Saturday, the House passed a bill reflecting a deal with his administration to provide billions of dollars to help sick workers and to prop up a slumping economy.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Is There Really a Toilet Paper Shortage?
articles.snippet: The household staple has consistently been out of stock during the coronavirus outbreak. Manufacturers may not be willing to increase supplies.
articles.abstract: The household staple has consistently been out of stock during the coronavirus outbreak. Manufacturers may not be willing to increase supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there’s one image that captures the panic seeping through the United States this week, it might be the empty store shelves where toilet paper usually sits.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Stocks Surge After Trump Promises Speedier Coronavirus Testing
articles.snippet: President Trump, surrounded by business leaders, said coronavirus tests would soon be more widely available. Investors pushed the market up nearly 10 percent.
articles.abstract: President Trump, surrounded by business leaders, said coronavirus tests would soon be more widely available. Investors pushed the market up nearly 10 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market roared back to life on Friday, with the S&P surging 9.3 percent after President Trump said the government would speed up coronavirus testing for Americans. In doing so, he delivered investors exactly the message they had been waiting to hear — a half-hour before the market closed.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips

articles.headline: The Coronavirus Swamps Local Health Departments, Already Crippled by Cuts
articles.snippet: Many state and municipal health departments saw budget and staffing cuts a decade ago that were never restored.
articles.abstract: Many state and municipal health departments saw budget and staffing cuts a decade ago that were never restored.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A widespread failure in the United States to invest in public health has left local and state health departments struggling to respond to the coronavirus outbreak and ill-prepared to face the swelling crisis ahead.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: He Has 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer and Nowhere to Sell Them
articles.snippet: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
articles.abstract: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
articles.lead_paragraph: On March 1, the day after the first coronavirus death in the United States was announced, brothers Matt and Noah Colvin set out in a silver S.U.V. to pick up some hand sanitizer. Driving around Chattanooga, Tenn., they hit a Dollar Tree, then a Walmart, a Staples and a Home Depot. At each store, they cleaned out the shelves.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas

articles.headline: A Conservative Agenda Unleashed on the Federal Courts
articles.snippet: President Trump’s imprint on the nation’s appeals courts has been swift and historic. He has named judges with records on a range of issues important to Republicans — and to his re-election.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s imprint on the nation’s appeals courts has been swift and historic. He has named judges with records on a range of issues important to Republicans — and to his re-election.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a Republican candidate for the Texas Supreme Court, Don R. Willett flaunted his uncompromising conservatism, boasting of endorsements from groups with “pro-life, pro-faith, pro-family” credentials.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Robert Gebeloff, Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: On a Saturday Night in Florida, a Presidential Party Became a Coronavirus Hot Zone
articles.snippet: A weekend getaway at Mar-a-Lago put the president in contact with several people who later tested positive for the virus. The White House physician said the president had tested negative for the virus.
articles.abstract: A weekend getaway at Mar-a-Lago put the president in contact with several people who later tested positive for the virus. The White House physician said the president had tested negative for the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lights were low and the disco balls spinning as a cake with a fiery sparkler shooting flames into the air was brought out to a robust rendition of “Happy Birthday,” joined by President Trump. The birthday girl, Kimberly Guilfoyle, the girlfriend of Donald Trump Jr., then pumped her fist in the air and called out, “Four more years!”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Shutdowns Spread Across Europe as Spain and France Order Broad Restrictions
articles.snippet: Other European countries are turning to border closures to try to contain the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Other European countries are turning to border closures to try to contain the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The shutdown of Europe expanded drastically on Saturday as more countries shuttered businesses, locked up borders and chased people off streets and into their homes in a race to contain the growing threat of the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter, Raphael Minder and Elian Peltier

articles.headline: Trump Oversold a Google Site to Fight Coronavirus
articles.snippet: After Jared Kushner liked the idea, President Trump inflated the concept. The disconnect is the latest example of the president exaggerating or making wholly inaccurate statements about his administration’s response.
articles.abstract: After Jared Kushner liked the idea, President Trump inflated the concept. The disconnect is the latest example of the president exaggerating or making wholly inaccurate statements about his administration’s response.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It started as a series of conversations this past week between officials working with Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law, and the chief executive of Verily, a life sciences subsidiary of Google’s parent company, about how it might help the Trump administration in the fight against the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Coronavirus Cost to Businesses and Workers: ‘It Has All Gone to Hell’
articles.snippet: As the outbreak forces the cancellation of trips, nights out and large gatherings, economic damage is mounting across the country.
articles.abstract: As the outbreak forces the cancellation of trips, nights out and large gatherings, economic damage is mounting across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week ago, Mark Canlis’s restaurant in Seattle was offering a $135 tasting menu to a bustling dining room every night. Eileen Hornor’s inn on the Maine coast was booking rooms for the busy spring graduation season. And Kalena Masching, a real estate agent in California, was fielding multiple offers on a $1.2 million home.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Patricia Cohen, Stacy Cowley, Conor Dougherty, Nicholas Kulish, David McCabe and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Arizona Boom Draws Californians and Changes Political Hue
articles.snippet: A decade after the recession hit hard, Arizona’s economy is a magnet for technology companies and for workers seeking an affordable middle-class life.
articles.abstract: A decade after the recession hit hard, Arizona’s economy is a magnet for technology companies and for workers seeking an affordable middle-class life.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Colin Jordan, a 32-year-old software salesman, lists various predictable reasons for his move to Scottsdale from the San Francisco Bay Area. He likes sun and golf and lower income taxes. But beneath all that is something bigger, which is the feeling that Arizona has welcomed him in ways that California — where he grew up — did not.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Europeans Erect Borders Against Coronavirus, but the Enemy Is Already Within
articles.snippet: In societies where life plays out on the street or in the cafe, where friends are greeted with kisses on the cheeks, the outbreak is creating fear and fragmentation.
articles.abstract: In societies where life plays out on the street or in the cafe, where friends are greeted with kisses on the cheeks, the outbreak is creating fear and fragmentation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The “gilded museum” of Europe is hollow and echoing. The great squares and stadiums are empty, the museums shut, the churches hesitant about services, the fine restaurants and cool bars shuttered.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Ahead of the Pack, How Microsoft Told Workers to Stay Home
articles.snippet: Its executives, with headquarters just a few miles from one of the country’s worst coronavirus outbreaks, were among the first to confront the impact.
articles.abstract: Its executives, with headquarters just a few miles from one of the country’s worst coronavirus outbreaks, were among the first to confront the impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, was at home, relaxing after a trip to India and Indonesia, when he started seeing news alerts on his phone.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise

articles.headline: Movie Crowds Stay Away. Theaters Hope It’s Not for Good.
articles.snippet: Cinemas, already contending with streaming services, are now facing the prospect of no audiences and no new films because of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.abstract: Cinemas, already contending with streaming services, are now facing the prospect of no audiences and no new films because of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For most of last week, movie theater executives clung grimly on.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Fed Slashes Rates to Near-Zero and Unveils Sweeping Program to Aid Economy
articles.snippet: The central bank cut rates by a full percentage point and announced a giant bond-buying campaign to insulate the economy against coronavirus fallout.
articles.abstract: The central bank cut rates by a full percentage point and announced a giant bond-buying campaign to insulate the economy against coronavirus fallout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the fast-spreading coronavirus posing a dire threat to economic growth, the Federal Reserve on Sunday night took the dramatic step of slashing interest rates to near-zero and unveiled a sweeping set of programs in an effort backstop the United States economy.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: When Facebook Is More Trustworthy Than the President
articles.snippet: Social media companies are delivering reliable information in the coronavirus crisis. Why can’t they do that all the time?
articles.abstract: Social media companies are delivering reliable information in the coronavirus crisis. Why can’t they do that all the time?
articles.lead_paragraph: For some Americans, reality arrived Jan. 25, when a Harvard epidemiologist tweeted “HOLY MOTHER OF GOD.” Or on Feb. 29, when researchers announced they had found cases in Seattle.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Biden and Sanders Fight Over Policy and Records in Head-to-Head Debate
articles.snippet: With the coronavirus as a backdrop, and with no audience in attendance, the two Democrats were at times feisty discussing their differences over health care. Mr. Biden also committed to choosing a woman as a running mate.
articles.abstract: With the coronavirus as a backdrop, and with no audience in attendance, the two Democrats were at times feisty discussing their differences over health care. Mr. Biden also committed to choosing a woman as a running mate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Senator Bernie Sanders called for vastly more aggressive government action to battle the coronavirus but split over some of the details along familiar ideological lines on Sunday night, as the two Democrats tangled over the right to lead their party into a campaign overshadowed by the pandemic inflicting havoc on the country’s economy and its social fabric.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Does Florida Really Want Ex-Felons to Vote?
articles.snippet: Former prisoners can now go to the polls. But fines remain one obstacle. Believing anything will make a difference is another. That’s where Julius Irving comes in.
articles.abstract: Former prisoners can now go to the polls. But fines remain one obstacle. Believing anything will make a difference is another. That’s where Julius Irving comes in.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — The two men were strangers and stood steps from the courthouse that had once sent them both to prison. Julius Irving spoke first.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: McConnell Has a Request for Veteran Federal Judges: Please Quit
articles.snippet: The Senate majority leader has encouraged judges thinking about stepping down to do so soon to ensure that Republicans confirm their replacements this year.
articles.abstract: The Senate majority leader has encouraged judges thinking about stepping down to do so soon to ensure that Republicans confirm their replacements this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Running out of federal court vacancies to fill, Senate Republicans have been quietly making overtures to sitting Republican-nominated judges who are eligible to retire to urge them to step aside so they can be replaced while the party still holds the Senate and the White House.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse

articles.headline: So We’re Working From Home. Can the Internet Handle It?
articles.snippet: With millions of people working and learning from home during the pandemic, internet networks are set to be strained to the hilt.
articles.abstract: With millions of people working and learning from home during the pandemic, internet networks are set to be strained to the hilt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Derek Pando rarely had problems with his home internet service — until last week. That was when he began working from his house because of the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Davey Alba and Cecilia Kang
